thread.title: 'Jeannie' exhibit on display at history center
thread.title_full: 'Jeannie' exhibit on display at history center

title: 'Jeannie' exhibit on display at history center
text:
'Jeannie' exhibit on display at history center Jennifer Sangalang , FLORIDA TODAY 2:52 p.m. EDT October 15, 2015 "I Dream of Jeannie" actress Barbara Eden visited the Space Coast in June 1969, specifically, the Air Force Space and Missile Museum. (Photo: PHOTO COURTESY OF AIR FORCE SPACE AND MISSILE MUSEUM) 
The space museum, which is on base at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, has been closed to the public since May, director Emily Perry said. The nearby history center, however, is definitely open and a suitable place to showcase items from the iconic "I Dream of Jeannie" TV show, which aired from 1965-70.The staff at the Air Force Space and Missile Museum are such fans of "I Dream of Jeannie," they want to share their exhibit with Brevard. They just had to move it first. 
"It's kind of like the best kept secret in Brevard," Perry said of the space museum. In 2010, the Air Force Space and Missile History Center opened. "It's a 3,200-square-foot facility that's got all kinds of exhibits, engines, nose cones, tons of photographs, and a really big gift shop." 
The "Jeannie" exhibit coincides with a visit from actress Barbara Eden, who played the title role alongside co-star Larry Hagman as her love-interest/master, Major Tony Nelson. 
Eden will be in Brevard on Oct. 25 to officiate the awards ceremony of the Ron Jon Cocoa Beach Half Marathon and for her performance, "On the Magic Carpet with Barbara Eden" at Holy Trinity Episcopal Academy in Melbourne. 
Story continues below 
An "I Dream of Jeannie" exhibit is on display at the Air Force Space and Missile History Center. (Photo: PHOTO COURTESY OF AIR FORCE SPACE AND MISSILE MUSEUM) 
"Everybody loves 'I Dream of Jeannie,'" Perry said. "We're big fans. She's been a friend to the museum and has been here several times in the past." Eden previously visited the space museum in June 1969, the same day she launched a weather rocket from the Cape, Perry added. Black-and-white photos from the museum archive show Eden standing in front of a "genie" missile. 
Some of the items on display include autographed photos by Eden, a genie bottle, Christmas ornaments, comic book covers, and an "I Dream of Jeannie" license plate. 
Contact Sangalang at 321-242-3630
